page.title: 20Historical interest.
page.content: The{Capon Tree Stone}marks the site of the Capon Tree, from whose branches, on October the 21st, 1746ad were hung six local men for their active adherence to the cause of the Royal Line of Stewart. The original Capon Tree was a large Oak growing on common land, half a mile from Brampton on the old Carlisle-Newcastle road. The name is thought to originate from the fact that circuit judges, riding on horseback from Newcastle to Carlisle with their attendant barristers, attorneys, clerks, servants and armed escort used this site to stop for rest and refreshment. Many were corrupt and accepted bribes of fat chickens and wine from the local people. They were known as 'Capon Justices'. The{Written stone of Gelt}shows indecipherable markings which are thought to date from Roman times.
